comment.author: 43854658@N00
comment._content: From: Florida State Parks .org "In the 1920s, Rainbow Springs was a favorite spot for tourists and locals. As the attraction grew, the river was dredged for glass bottom boat tours; and waterfalls were built on piles of phosphate tailings. A zoo, rodeo, gift shops and a monorail with leaf-shaped gondolas were added. In the mid-1970s, when larger theme parks lured the tourists away, Rainbow Springs was closed. In the mid-1990s, it reopened as a state park. In 1972, the U.S. Department of the Interior designated Rainbow River as a National Natural Landmark. It is also an aquatic preserve and an Outstanding Florida Water."

comment.author: 31846825@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pixelwrangler] Thanks Pixel! Listen to glass bottom boat captain Skipper Locket perform part of his Rainbow Springs chant at the Stephen Foster Folk Culture Center (White Springs, FL) in 1956: floridamemory.com/audio/occupational.php#07.
comment.authorname: State Library and Archives of Florida

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/floridamemory] That two-minute clip is fantastic!   I don't think anyone could listen to it without having a smile on their face! ;)
